title: Anger over ‘swastika’ outside Indian restaurant that’s actually a peace symbol
text:
Some people have refused to visit Lily’s ‘whilst they have a swastika over the door’ (Picture: Lily’s Vegetarian Indian Cuisine)

A curry house is standing its ground after receiving backlash over a swastika it has displayed outside.

Lily’s Vegetarian Indian Restaurant took to social media to fight back against negative comments made about their entrance.

The venue in Ashton-under-Lyne, Greater Manchester, have used the ancient version of the swastika, which is a symbol of peace.

But the emblem was twisted, literally and figuratively, by the Nazi Party in the 1930s, permanently tainting it in the minds of many people.

One would-be customer said they would refuse to set foot in Lily’s ‘whilst they have a swastika over the door’.

But the Indian restaurant says they are using an ancient spiritual symbol of peace (Picture Lily’s Vegetarian Indian Cuisine)

Fans of the restaurant jumped to its defence and said it was a ‘shame’ and ‘absolutely pathetic’ that they were forced to explain themselves.

One wrote: ‘The symbol was misappropriated by the Nazis. People should be informed of its true meaning.’

The swastika used by the far-right is rotated degrees and is usually a black character within a white circle on a red background.

The word itself comes from Sanskrit meaning ‘conducive to wellbeing’ or ‘auspicious’, while in Hinduism it symbolises prosperity and good luck.

Fans of the curry house said it was ‘pathetic’ that they were forced to defend themselves (Picture: Lily’s Vegetarian Indian Cuisine)

The swastika at Lily’s is red on a white background, and is part of a welcome sign hung above the door before a visit from Mayor of Tameside.

Councillor Leigh Drennan visited the restaurant last night as part of the pre-Diwali celebrations.

In a bid to shake off the Swastika’s negative connotations, a post on Lily’s Facebook page reads: ‘The symbol that is used in this sign is a religious Hindu symbol. It is an ancient symbol of spirituality and represents auspiciousness and good luck.

Management said the symbol has been recognised since 3000 BC, long before the Nazi regime (Picture: Lily’s Vegetarian Indian Cuisine)

‘It has been recognised as this symbol since 3000 BC and still represents this for many Hindus around the world today.

‘We have been made aware that some comments have been circulating that imply we have this symbol up for other reasons and would like to make it clear that this isn’t the case.’

Lily’s Vegetarian recently celebrated winning a Manchester Food and Drink Festival award for Neighbourhood Restaurant of the Year, just a year after being awarded Vegetarian Offering of the Year.
